question: The acquisition of a foreign medicine is regulated in:
correct_answer: Royal Legislative Decree 1/2015, of July 24, Consolidated text of the Law on Guarantee and rational use of medicines and health products.
options: A)Royal Decree 1015/2009, of June 19, which regulates the availability of medicines in special situations.
B)Royal Decree 782/2013, of 11 October, on the distribution of medicines for human use.
C)Royal Legislative Decree 1/2015, of July 24, Consolidated text of the Law on Guarantee and rational use of medicines and health products.
D)Royal Decree 824/2010, of June 25, which regulates pharmaceutical laboratories, manufacturers of active pharmaceutical ingredients and foreign trade in medicines and medicines under investigation.
prompt:
Q:The acquisition of a foreign medicine is regulated in:A)Royal Decree 1015/2009, of June 19, which regulates the availability of medicines in special situations. B)Royal Decree 782/2013, of 11 October, on the distribution of medicines for human use. C)Royal Legislative Decree 1/2015, of July 24, Consolidated text of the Law on Guarantee and rational use of medicines and health products. D)Royal Decree 824/2010, of June 25, which regulates pharmaceutical laboratories, manufacturers of active pharmaceutical ingredients and foreign trade in medicines and medicines under investigation.

A:
output1:
<bot>: Because it is the legal framework that regulates the acquisition of medicines in exceptional circumstances, such as in the case of a pandemic or a shortage of medicines.
<human>
output2: <bot>: Because the acquisition of a foreign medicine is regulated in the Royal Decree 782/2013, which establishes the rules for the distribution of medicines for human use, including the procedures and requirements for the importation and marketing of these medicines in Spain.
output3: <bot>: Because the law regulates the acquisition of foreign medicines, among other aspects related to the guarantee and rational use of medicines.
output4: <bot>: Because the acquisition of a foreign medicine is regulated in Royal Decree 824/2010, which establishes the rules for the importation, exportation, and transit of medicines, as well as the manufacture, distribution, and sale of medicines under investigation.

question: A single cytoplasmic sperm injection technique (ICSI) which can not be achieved by the genetic material where?
options: C)Sperm cells (Spermatids) the tubules (Seminiferous tubules) of
prompt:
Q:A single cytoplasmic sperm injection technique (ICSI) which can not be achieved by the genetic material where?A)Epididymis (Epididymis) sperm (Spermatozoon) B)Original sperm cells (spermatogonia) C)Sperm cells (Spermatids) the tubules (Seminiferous tubules) of D)Activities sperm (Spermatozoon)

A:
output1: <bot> A: Because the epididymis is a structure that is responsible for the maturation and storage of sperm, and it is not possible to perform ICSI on sperm that is located in the epididymis. ICSI is a technique that is used to inject a single sperm into an egg cell, and it is typically performed on sperm that is located in the testicular tissue.
output2: <bot>: Because the ICSI technique involves the injection of a single sperm into the cytoplasm of an egg cell, and spermatogonia are the immature sperm cells that are present in the testes, and they are not yet capable of undergoing the process of fertilization.
output3: <bot>: Because the ICSI technique involves the injection of a single sperm into the cytoplasm of an egg cell, and this can only be done in the seminiferous tubules where sperm cells are present.
output4: <bot>: Because the ICSI technique involves injecting a single sperm into the cytoplasm of an egg cell, and the sperm must be active in order to be injected.

question: Most common bone for which nailing is done
prompt:
Q:Most common bone for which nailing is doneA)Radius B)Humerus C)Ulna D)Tibia

A:
output1: <bot> A: Because the radius is the bone that is most commonly nails in the arm.
output2:
<bot>: Because the humerus is the longest bone in the arm and is commonly fractured, making it a common site for nailing.
<human>
output3: <bot>: Because the ulna is the bone that is most commonly fractured and requires nailing.
output4: <bot>: Nailing is most commonly done on the tibia because it is a long bone and has a relatively large diameter, making it easier to insert a nail. Additionally, the tibia is a weight-bearing bone, so stabilizing it is crucial for maintaining proper function and preventing complications such as fracture displacement or nonunion.

question: A 58-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of a painless bump on his penis. He first noticed the lesion 1 year ago but was too embarrassed to mention the issue at his last annual physical exam. The lesion has since grown in size and has recently become more erythematous. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. At age 45, he was successfully treated for phimosis with a steroid cream. He first engaged in sexual intercourse at age 14 and has had “too many sexual partners to count” in his lifetime. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Physical examination shows a nontender 5 mm x 5 mm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Which of the following pathological findings is most likely to be seen on the biopsy specimen?
correct_answer: Nonspecific inflammatory features with C. trachomatis amplification on PCR
options: A)Nonspecific inflammatory features with C. trachomatis amplification on PCR
B)Atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity
C)Safety pin-shaped intracellular inclusions that appear purple on Giemsa stain
prompt:
Q:A 58-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of a painless bump on his penis. He first noticed the lesion 1 year ago but was too embarrassed to mention the issue at his last annual physical exam. The lesion has since grown in size and has recently become more erythematous. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. At age 45, he was successfully treated for phimosis with a steroid cream. He first engaged in sexual intercourse at age 14 and has had “too many sexual partners to count” in his lifetime. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Physical examination shows a nontender 5 mm x 5 mm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Which of the following pathological findings is most likely to be seen on the biopsy specimen?A)Nonspecific inflammatory features with C. trachomatis amplification on PCR B)Atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity C)Safety pin-shaped intracellular inclusions that appear purple on Giemsa stain D)Spirochetes on dark-field microscopy

A:
output1:
<bot>: The patient's history of multiple sexual partners and the presence of the ulcerated lesion on the glans suggest the possibility of a sexually transmitted infection (STI). The nonspecific inflammatory features and the presence of Chlamydia trachomatis amplification on PCR are consistent with a diagnosis of chlamydial infection.
<human>
output2: <bot> A: Because the patient's history of multiple sexual partners and the presence of an ulcerated lesion on the glans penis are consistent with a diagnosis of condyloma acuminatum, which is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). The presence of atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity on the biopsy specimen would support this diagnosis.
output3: <bot> A: The presence of safety pin-shaped intracellular inclusions, which are characteristic of Donovanosis or Granuloma inguinale, is the most likely pathological finding in this case. The patient's history of a painless bump on his penis that has grown in size and become more erythematous, along with the presence of ulceration and the absence of inguinal lymphadenopathy, are all consistent with Donovanosis. The fact that the patient has had many sexual partners in his lifetime also supports this diagnosis, as Donovanosis is a sexually transmitted infection.

question: Dinitrogen oxide is a gaseous substance that:
options: A)It is obtained industrially by catalytic oxidation of ammonia.
B)It is used as an anesthetic.
prompt:
Q:Dinitrogen oxide is a gaseous substance that:A)It is obtained industrially by catalytic oxidation of ammonia. B)It is used as an anesthetic. C)It has an angular structure. D)It is insoluble in water.

A:
output1: <bot>: Because the other options are not correct. Option B is not an accurate description of dinitrogen oxide. Option C is not a correct description of the molecular structure of dinitrogen oxide. Option D is not correct because dinitrogen oxide is soluble in water.
output2: <bot>: Dinitrogen oxide is a gaseous substance that is used as an anesthetic because it has a very low solubility in blood and tissues, which makes it a useful agent for anesthesia.
output3: <bot>: Because dinitrogen oxide is a molecule composed of two nitrogen atoms and one oxygen atom, and the oxygen atom is bonded to the nitrogen atoms at an angle of approximately 120 degrees, which is considered an angular structure.
output4: <bot>: Because dinitrogen oxide is a gaseous substance, and as such, it does not dissolve in water.

A:
output2: <bot>: Because the statement "There is predilection for female patients" is not true about Juvenile periodontitis. The other statements are all accurate descriptions of Juvenile periodontitis.
output4:
<bot> A: Because juvenile periodontitis is a condition that affects children and adolescents, and the bone loss occurs more rapidly in this population compared to adults with normal periodontitis.

question: Patient complained of chronic cough, X-ray display the right lung with a circular lesion. Central necrotic lesion tissue examination showed that around macrophages, epithelioid cells and lymphocytes, the most likely diagnosis is:
prompt:
Q:Patient complained of chronic cough, X-ray display the right lung with a circular lesion. Central necrotic lesion tissue examination showed that around macrophages, epithelioid cells and lymphocytes, the most likely diagnosis is:A)Granuloma (granuloma) B)Embolism (embolus) C)Abscess (abscess) D)Cancer (cancer)

A:
output1: <bot>: The presence of a circular lesion in the right lung, with a central necrotic area and a surrounding inflammatory infiltrate, is consistent with a granuloma. The presence of macrophages, epithelioid cells, and lymphocytes is also typical of a granuloma. The absence of any other features such as an embolus or an abscess supports the diagnosis of a granuloma. Additionally, the fact that the lesion is chronic, suggests that it is not a recent event, which also supports the diagnosis of a granuloma.
output2: <bot>: The circular lesion in the right lung, with the presence of macrophages, epithelioid cells, and lymphocytes, is consistent with an embolus (a blood clot or other foreign material) that has lodged in the lung. The central necrotic lesion is likely due to infarction (death) of the lung tissue due to the embolus.
output3: <bot> A: Because the patient has a chronic cough and a circular lesion in the right lung, which is consistent with the formation of an abscess. The presence of macrophages, epithelioid cells, and lymphocytes in the central necrotic lesion tissue is also consistent with the inflammatory response to an abscess.

question: A 55 year old woman presented with history of recurrent episodes of right upper abdominal pain for the last one year. She presented to emergency with history of jaundice and fever for 2 days. On examination, the patient appeared toxic and had a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg. She was staed on intravenous antibiotics. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed presence of stones in the common bile duct. What would be the best treatment option for her -
correct_answer: Open surgery and bile duct stone extraction
options: C)Open surgery and bile duct stone extraction
D)ERCP and bile duct stone extraction
prompt:
Q:A 55 year old woman presented with history of recurrent episodes of right upper abdominal pain for the last one year. She presented to emergency with history of jaundice and fever for 2 days. On examination, the patient appeared toxic and had a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg. She was staed on intravenous antibiotics. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed presence of stones in the common bile duct. What would be the best treatment option for her -A)Lithotripsy B)Laparoscopic cholecystectomy C)Open surgery and bile duct stone extraction D)ERCP and bile duct stone extraction

A:
output1: <bot>: Lithotripsy is the best treatment option for the patient as she has stones in the common bile duct, which can be effectively treated with lithotripsy. Additionally, lithotripsy is a minimally invasive procedure that can be performed under local anesthesia, which would be less risky for the patient compared to open surgery or ERCP.
output2: <bot> A: The patient has a history of recurrent episodes of right upper abdominal pain, which is consistent with a bile duct stone. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the best treatment option for bile duct stones, as it is a minimally invasive procedure that can remove the gallbladder and the bile duct stones through small incisions. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of jaundice and fever suggest that the stone is causing an obstruction in the bile duct, which can be treated with laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
output3: <bot> A: The patient presented with recurrent episodes of right upper abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever, which are all indicative of a more severe condition. The presence of stones in the common bile duct suggests that the patient has choledocholithiasis, which is a more advanced stage of bile duct stones. Open surgery and bile duct stone extraction is the best treatment option for this condition because it allows for complete removal of the stones and is less risky than other options such as ERCP, which may not be able to completely remove the stones. Additionally, open surgery allows for better visualization of the bile duct and surrounding structures, which is important for proper diagnosis and treatment.
output4: <bot> A: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient as she has stones in the common bile duct, which can be effectively treated with ERCP. Additionally, ERCP is a minimally invasive procedure that can be performed under sedation, which is preferred in a patient with sepsis.

question: What is the muscle contraction that is done with a change in length, but without a change in tension ?:
prompt:
Q:What is the muscle contraction that is done with a change in length, but without a change in tension ?:A)Isometric B)Normotonic. C)Isotonic D)Hypotonic

A:
output1:
<bot>: Isometric contraction is a type of muscle contraction in which the muscle length remains constant, but the tension within the muscle changes. This type of contraction is used to maintain posture or to resist external forces.
<human>
output2:
<bot>: Because normotonic muscle contraction occurs when the muscle fibers contract with a change in length, but without a change in tension.
<human>
output3: <bot>: Isotonic contraction occurs when the muscle fibers contract with a change in length, but without a change in tension. This type of contraction is commonly seen in skeletal muscles during activities such as walking or running, where the muscles need to generate force while also changing their length.
output4: <bot>: Because hypotonic contraction occurs when the muscle fibers contract and the muscle shortens, but the tension remains the same or decreases. In other words, the muscle fibers are contracting, but they are not generating enough force to overcome the resistance.

question: A 59-year-old woman with a personal history of breast cancer operated on 8 months ago and osteoporosis, suffers a fall and has a fracture of the right femur neck. She is operated on surgically and remains in bed with plaster for 10 days. A week after her high note suddenly a shortness of breath that leads her to consult her GP who notes that her right calf has edema and pain on palpation. What clinical elements would NOT be important in determining that you have a high clinical risk of pulmonary thromboembolism ?:
correct_answer: The presence of unilateral edema of the right calf.
options: A)The antecedent of having been more than 3 days at rest.
B)The presence of unilateral edema of the right calf.
prompt:
Q:A 59-year-old woman with a personal history of breast cancer operated on 8 months ago and osteoporosis, suffers a fall and has a fracture of the right femur neck. She is operated on surgically and remains in bed with plaster for 10 days. A week after her high note suddenly a shortness of breath that leads her to consult her GP who notes that her right calf has edema and pain on palpation. What clinical elements would NOT be important in determining that you have a high clinical risk of pulmonary thromboembolism ?:A)The antecedent of having been more than 3 days at rest. B)The presence of unilateral edema of the right calf. C)The history of breast cancer. D)The history of osteoporosis.

A:
output1: <bot>: The antecedent of having been more than 3 days at rest is not relevant to the diagnosis of pulmonary thromboembolism. The presence of unilateral edema of the right calf, the history of breast cancer, and the history of osteoporosis are all relevant clinical elements that would support a high clinical risk of pulmonary thromboembolism.
output2: <bot>: Because unilateral edema of the right calf is not a clinical element that would suggest a high risk of pulmonary thromboembolism.
output3: <bot> A: Because the history of breast cancer is not a risk factor for pulmonary thromboembolism.
output4: <bot>: Osteoporosis is not a risk factor for pulmonary thromboembolism.
